title: Castles + Adventure Combos for Families

content:
Wales has castles galore, but why just look at them? Here's how to combine historical sightseeing with a dose of adventure the whole family will enjoy.

# Castles + Adventure Combos for Families

Let's face it, dragging the kids around yet *another* castle keep can be a recipe for moans and glazed-over eyes. But Wales is bursting with options to mix history with a bit of adrenaline. Here are a few ideas to get you started, with costs for the 2025/2026 season.

## North Wales: Castles & Zip Lines

North Wales boasts some of the most impressive castles in the country, and handily, Zip World has several locations nearby. This is perfect if you're based around Llandudno, Conwy or are coming over from the North West of England.

### Conwy Castle & Zip World Fforest

Conwy Castle is a proper medieval fortress, right on the quayside in the town of Conwy. It's easy to access, with plenty of parking in the town (pay and display). Spend a couple of hours exploring the towers and walls – the views across the estuary are great.

Then, a short 15-minute drive inland brings you to Zip World Fforest near Betws-y-Coed. This place is spot-on for families. The *Fforest Coaster* (toboggan run, £25-£35) is a guaranteed crowd-pleaser and suitable for young kids. There's also *Tree Hoppers*, a high ropes course, and *Zip Safari*. It’s a well-organized setup but it can get busy, so booking ahead is essential. You could easily spend the entire day here.

**Verdict:** This combo suits families with younger kids (5+) who are up for some low-to-mid level thrills. Older teens might prefer the Velocity 2 Zip Line.

### Caernarfon Castle & Bounce Below

Caernarfon Castle is visually stunning. It's a World Heritage Site for good reason. This is a bigger castle and warrants at least 3 hours, plus it's right in town, so you'll find lots of shops and cafes. Parking is ample but not free, it's in the town's pay-and-display car parks.

Afterwards, drive 30 minutes to Blaenau Ffestiniog and *Bounce Below* at Zip World Llechwedd. This is essentially giant trampolines in a disused slate mine (costs £25-£35). It's a unique experience. The temperature underground is a consistent 10 degrees Celsius, so bring a light jacket even in summer. They provide overalls and helmets.

**Verdict:** This is a good option for a rainy day, and caters well to families with younger kids, but not those with mobility issues due to the number of steps down into the mine. If you're into industrial history, then combine Bounce Below with the *Underground Adventure* mine tour (also at Llechwedd, £20-35).

## Snowdonia: History & Hiking

Snowdonia National Park isn't *just* about castles. It's about mountains! So you can easily combine a historic site with a walk.

### Dolbadarn Castle & Llanberis Path

Dolbadarn Castle is a small, but perfectly formed ruin overlooking Llyn Peris near Llanberis. It's free to access and doesn't require much time – 30-45 minutes is usually enough. There is a free car park, but it fills up fast, especially in the summer.

From here, you can tackle a section of the Llanberis Path up Snowdon. This is the easiest route to the summit, but it's still a serious undertaking. If you have younger kids, just walk as far as you feel comfortable and then turn back. Even a short walk offers fantastic views. You can hire a guide from *MountainXperience* for a full ascent (£45-£65). Allow a full day for the hike. Be aware that weather on Snowdon can change rapidly. Come prepared with waterproofs, warm layers, and sturdy boots, even in summer.

**Verdict:** This is a good option for families with some hiking experience.

### Harlech Castle & Coastal Walk

Harlech Castle is another impressive coastal fortress. The views from the battlements are amazing, stretching along the Cardigan Bay coastline. Parking is available in the town, but can be busy in peak season.

After the castle, take a walk along the Wales Coast Path. A section south towards Llandanwg is relatively easy, offering stunning views of the beach and dunes. You could combine this with a paddle in the sea (if you're brave enough!).

**Verdict:** This is a less strenuous option than hiking Snowdon, suitable for families of all ages and fitness levels. And a great place to take the dog.

## Pembrokeshire: Coastal Castles & Coasteering

Pembrokeshire Coast National Park has more than its fair share of castles, and what better to combine that with than some time in the water?

### Pembroke Castle & Coasteering

Pembroke Castle is one of the largest and most impressive castles in Wales, and birthplace of Henry VII. It's well worth a visit. Parking is available in the town, but it can get crowded in the summer.

From here, head to Stackpole Quay (20 minutes' drive) and book a coasteering session with *TYF Adventure* or *Preseli Venture* (around £60 per person). Coasteering involves scrambling along the coastline, swimming in the sea, and jumping off rocks. It’s an exhilarating experience, and perfectly safe with experienced guides. Wetsuits and all safety gear are provided. This is an all levels activity, though it is best to be a reasonable swimmer.

**Verdict:** This is a great option for adventurous families who enjoy being in the sea. The minimum age is usually around 8 years old. For older more adventurous teenagers, this can be combined with surfing lessons.

## Considerations

*   **Weather:** Wales is notorious for its unpredictable weather. Always check the forecast before you set out, and be prepared for rain, even in summer.
*   **Booking:** Many adventure activities require advance booking, especially during peak season (school holidays).
*   **Fitness Levels:** Be realistic about your family's fitness levels when choosing an activity. There's no shame in opting for a shorter walk or a less strenuous activity.
*   **Alternatives:** If castles aren't your thing, consider combining your adventure activity with a visit to a local museum or a scenic drive. The *Brecon Beacons* also offer fantastic adventure opportunities.

So, there you have it. A few ideas to inject some adventure into your Welsh castle visit. Get out there and explore!
